Nouse Albums Club - February '11

15/03/2011

Another month and another batch of reviews from Nouse's, ever-growing in numbers, underground music cabal.

Image by

By James Bithell

Another month and another batch of reviews from Nouse's, ever-growing in numbers, underground music cabal. We've judged last month's big records: giving The Streets, Lykke Li and Bright Eyes our blessing, but condemning Lil B's debut album to a stoning. Radiohead's out-of-the-blue release nearly resulted in a putsch, so to please both sides we're included two opposing reviews. The revolution will be reviewed using a 10 point scoring system.
The Streets Computers and Blues Mike Skinner has had enough. Citing unhappiness with the name and connotations of the 2002 breakthrough act, Computers and Blues is the last chapter in The Streets saga and a bittersweet farewell to one of the nation's most exciting garage outfits. With a back catalogue of Saturday night semi-anthems ("Fit But You Know It") and more genuine ballads ("The Escapist") under his belt, Skinner's style has often oscillated between irreverence and sincerity. It's good then that Computers and Blues acts as a suitable denouement for Skinner, coupling both his wit and more earnest moments in a final effort that is as captivating as his debut. It seems the case that the more things change, the more they stay the same for Skinner. Whilst chronicling the challenges of new fatherhood on "Blip On A Screen", Skinner shows he is still happiest when getting high or drunk with his mates, with "Roof Of Your Car" and "Without Thinking" recounting the pastimes in question. What's most apparent here is that on all of the fourteen tracks, the album never loses impetus or dies down, an indicator surely that Skinner has not given up the ghost just yet. In fact, all signs point towards Skinner playing a more behind-the-scenes role in future projects, whether as a producer or as a collaborator. Computers and Blues is an album that should win over old fans, as well as newcomers, to The Streets sensation. I'm not promising that you'll like it as much as Original Pirate Material, but it's clear at least that Skinner's gone out with a resounding bang, rather than a whimper. 9 Jai Jethwa
Radiohead King of Limbs Only a band as innovative and anti-consumerist as Radiohead could announce the release of their forthcoming album, The King of Limbs, five days before it goes on sale - and I, for one, love them for it. This is a band that needs no promotion or build-up - the music speaks for itself. Opener "Bloom" is brilliantly messy and experimental, setting the tone for the first half of the album; it sounds like In Rainbows on acid. The songs are made up of fragmented sounds, electronic samples strung together to make something unique and distinctive - this could only be Radiohead. While I love every track, the latter half of the record is near perfection. "Codex" is sublime, with just a simple piano backing, Thom Yorke manages to create a rich wall of sound with his beautiful haunting vocals - with clear parallels to "Pyramid Song". "Give up the Ghost" is similarly evocative, with the repetition of "Don't haunt me/Don't hurt me" echoing over layers of rich, lingering tones, it's a modern love song of understated brilliance. Radiohead effortlessly manage to pull off the impossible, their songs resonate with simple elegance, whilst simultaneously capturing the bleak outlook of a generation. Intimate yet abrasive, they use jittery rhythms, electronic beats and Yorke's distinctive voice to create something sinister yet beautiful. With this record they cement their place as one of the most ground-breaking, original bands around. 10 Becky Claypole
Radiohead might well be masters of internet trolling for all the intense hysteria provoked by their impromptu releases. For weeks, while the dust settled, no one was able to say much other than poke fun of Thom Yorke's dancing or ridiculously claim King of Limbs was a musical resurrection, here to save the dying record industry. King of Limbs threads much of the same IDM territory as its predecessor In Rainbows. Glitchy piano loops, dissonant bleeps and flickering percussion imbuing the first half with a jittery instability. Nothing quite stands out here: "Bloom" and "Morning Mr Magpie" are emotionally blunted by indecipherable lyrics, offering little other than an overall preoccupation with nature. After the animalistic electronic buzz of "Feral" the album reaches some sort of metaphorical oasis, with a more distinctly human subject matter and a more ambient tone. "Lotus Flower" has a stunning chorus, with Yorke's voice floating far above its drum beat. More beautiful yet is "Codex", with its delicate shimmering instrumentals, enticing you to "jump off the edge" into its unending depth. Although the only track offering a serious departure from In Rainbows is "Give Up The Ghost"; both deeply vulnerable with its backing repetition of "don't hurt me" and dismissingly confident with Yorke crooning "I think I should give up the ghost" over Greenwood's stripped down guitar strumming. It's almost a little embarrassing the reverence granted to Radiohead records, that if it isn't quite as obviously brilliant at first, it's excused as complex or difficult to grasp. If anything this is Radiohead's most low-key release to date; a subdued shrug rather than the head first experimentalism we've come to expect. King of Limbs is perhaps a necessary exhaling of old ideas for a band disillusioned by album releases. 6 Adam Bychawski
Bright Eyes The People's Key If this is the record that the near idolised folkie Conor Oberst chooses to retire the Bright Eyes collective with, it will certainly be a divisive one. The People's Key bids goodbye to the concrete (literal or otherwise) musings on the "sidewalks and the pigeons" of Midwest American solitude, in favour of an electric, synthesised exploration of cosmic spirituality and the future as "post-everything, like a child imagining". As the frontman proclaims on the romping "Triple Spiral", this record is a case of "in with the new, out with the old" - lyrically, sonically and musically. Admittedly, this sounds a bit like new-age rubbish. However, the result is slick, composed and secure in the hands of Oberst's masterful grasp of melody. At its best, The People's Key is euphoric and communal, from the woozy opener "Firewall", moulding spiralling guitars and militaristic drum rolls over Denny Brewer's monologue about time and pomegranates, to the positively catchy stomp of "Beginner's Mind" and the glitzy synths that fizz above Oberst's piano in "Shell Games". But it is this emphasis on the collective that occasionally undermines the record. For all the complex solidarity of "One for You, One for Me", the sheer poignancy of emotion driving tinkling piano ballad "Ladder Song" hints at the lonely angst that made early Bright Eyes records so powerfully affecting. However, it is clearly a very different sort of loneliness that Oberst is trying to portray, and the progression in sound is to be lauded. As the final line, "It's I and I" fades out, the listener is reminded of the lyrical voice still commanding attention amongst the album's electronic veneer. 7 Sam Briggs
Lykke Li Wounded Rhymes As a young musician there are certain terms you are unavoidably lumped with, such as "maturing" or "coming-of-age". Thankfully Lykke Li has admitted that in Wounded Rhymes "all the baby fat is gone" sparing us the trouble. Li has shed her skin of the teenage concerns portrayed in Youth Novels to reveal a far more provocative and sexually-charged side of herself. "I'm your prostitute, you gon' get some" she sings in the loaded refrain to album highlight "Get Some"; a song that resembles a musical spaghetti western standoff. Li doesn't hold back on Wounded Rhymes, its hooks are spelt out in big black letters. Obviously heartbreak is one major theme throughout but this isn't as simplistic as a break-up album; Li precariously tip-toes between pain and pleasure. Wounden Rhymes is as difficult to pin down musically as it is lyrically, ranging from stripped down minimalism ("I Know Places") to shoo-wop heartbreak ballads like "Unrequited Love" and the fierce steel-panned backed soul of "I Follow Rivers". Somehow all this instrumental variety comes naturally, what really jars are the lyrical contradictions; from love-loss to "Rich Kid Blues" to sexual independence, it's all a bit difficult to stomach together. Each track, however, is sung with such sensuality or mournful conviction that Li comes across as mostly believable rather than bi-polar. 7 Adam Bychawski
Lil B Angels Exodus Lil B is undoubtedly one of most abstract concepts I've had to explain in a review. Something of a rising hip hop star, the man has released over 200 songs of unfiltered musical diarrhoea through his YouTube channel. Most have in common an unashamed disregard for audio quality, lack of any rhyming or attention to timing, and out of place musical samples. Not to mention Lil B's near constant adlibbing of "SWAG" after every sentence or breath, his not so occasional sexual requests to his male listener's female partners and inexplicably bizarre obsession with dance moves miming cooking. That last paragraph was as serious explanation as you could offer, and it is still near incomprehensible. So it is something of a (pleasant) surprise to find that debut album Angels Exodus has almost nothing of the Lil B that has made him so infamous. Diverging from an obsession with celebrity name dropping and fellatio has surprisingly revealed a more poignant side to Lil B. Largely these serious tracks are sort of like a personal self-help hotline: "Exodus 9" has B reminding himself "Last time I failed/Is when I fell in love with distractions, while on "Motivation" B contemplates "That's what scares me, cause you fear what you can't see". Some tracks with potential are weirdly unfinished, abruptly ending after two minutes, others are awfully misguided; such as "All My Life (Remix)" in which Lil B off-tune wails its chorus, or "Vampires", in which B hypothesizes his life as a vampire. For an artist whose charm has been plucking out the occasional gem in a stream of turd, this album is no different. 5 Adam Bychawski
